claim: Antarctica has a lot of problems relating to homelessness.

supporting.text: Antarctica has no permanent human population, only temporary researchers and support staff, making homelessness irrelevant.

attacks.text: Antarctica has no permanent human population, only temporary researchers and support staff, making homelessness irrelevant.
Even temporary populations can experience homelessness if housing infrastructure fails.
Research stations in Antarctica are highly regulated with strict housing protocols, making housing failures extremely rare.
Homelessness could still occur if personnel are expelled from stations due to misconduct or emergencies.
Expelled personnel are typically evacuated from the continent entirely, preventing homelessness in Antarctica.

supporting.text: The extreme climate of Antarctica makes it uninhabitable without specialized infrastructure, preventing any form of homelessness.

attacks.text: The extreme climate of Antarctica makes it uninhabitable without specialized infrastructure, preventing any form of homelessness.
Scientific research stations in Antarctica house temporary populations, some of whom may face housing instability or lack of permanent accommodation.
Housing instability in research stations is managed by strict protocols and does not equate to homelessness as understood in populated regions.
There are no documented cases of homelessness in Antarctica, as all inhabitants are part of organized missions with guaranteed shelter.

supporting.text: All human presence in Antarctica is strictly regulated by international treaties, ensuring no unregulated or homeless populations exist.

attacks.text: All human presence in Antarctica is strictly regulated by international treaties, ensuring no unregulated or homeless populations exist.
Some research stations in Antarctica have reported cases of transient individuals who do not have official status, suggesting gaps in regulation enforcement.
International treaties like the Antarctic Treaty System are rigorously enforced by member nations, making unregulated presence highly unlikely.
Tourists and temporary workers sometimes overstay their permits, creating a gray area of unregulated presence.

supporting.text: Homelessness requires a societal structure with economic disparities, which is absent in Antarctica due to its non-permanent, research-focused inhabitants.

attacks.text: Homelessness requires a societal structure with economic disparities, which is absent in Antarctica due to its non-permanent, research-focused inhabitants.
Even in research stations, resource allocation issues can create temporary homelessness among support staff or visiting personnel.
Research stations have strict protocols ensuring all personnel have assigned accommodations, making temporary homelessness extremely unlikely.
Tourist expeditions to Antarctica sometimes strand participants due to logistical failures, creating short-term homelessness situations.
Tour operators maintain contingency plans and legal obligations to prevent homelessness scenarios, with evacuation protocols for all clients.

supporting.text: Antarctica's logistical challenges and lack of resources make it impossible for homeless individuals to survive without institutional support.

attacks.text: Antarctica's logistical challenges and lack of resources make it impossible for homeless individuals to survive without institutional support.
Antarctica has no permanent human population, so homelessness is not a relevant issue.
Even if homelessness were possible, extreme conditions deter any potential homeless individuals from residing there.
Scientific research stations provide institutional support, making homelessness a non-issue by design.
